job_title: Junior Research Specialist II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
+ cool city, great facilities, lucky to have ran into a good team.
+ very intellectually stimulating and interesting research.
cons:
+ expensive city and salary is not great. 
+ responsibilities can be technical and demands can sometimes be stressful.

review_title: Great place for researchers, but expensive to live as a post doc
job_title: Post Doc in San Francisco, CA
pros: resources for research are excellent, and full of career development resources for those who want to explore.
cons: PIs are loosing fundings and post doc positions depends on the PI or personal funding, unlike some research facilities which has internal funding.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great collection of scholars, leaders in many fields of the life sciences.
cons: Multiple campuses are not easy to travel between. Labs can be somewhat isolated. Very poor salaries for high cost of living San Francisco.

job_title: Junior Special in San Francisco, CA
pros: Easy commute, great benefits, easy to network between labs to get more research opportunities and collaborations
cons: Academia and thus pay is lower than one could want. Lots of 'training' to be done to be up to code for OSHA that involves just staring at videos for hours.

review_title: Good for postdoctors and graduate students
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: It is great place for young scientists to get  experience in research and learn from a large pool of prestigious professors.
cons: Business style managment in academic institution which is not viable for scientific discover and retaining of talented scientist. Promotion mostly is slow too.

review_title: Great collaboration among different fields. Awesome place to work.
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good balance between work and social environment. Great locality (Mission Bay) and wonderful shuttle service available. Staff are helpful to a great extent
cons: Not much internal communication available among the different departments. More inter-departmental seminars will instigate more innovative ideas.

review_title: They only care about the Medicine
job_title: Programmer/Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
If you are about medicine then it's the place to be. 
They are outsourcing the HR and IT.
cons: if you not about the medicine stay away.  UCSF is under tremendous stress to reduce costs and they are doing it by outsourcing all non medical jobs. They have outsources their HR to Irvine, they have outsourced their procurement system to Berkeley / Sci-quest. They must reduce their costs and employees sufferer.

job_title: Analyst IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good benefits, supportive work environment. Large ecosystem for advancement or for variety of jobs. Mission of advancing healthcare and medical care is excellent.
cons: Academic environment is slower moving than business environment and can seem bureaucratic. Salaries are not at open market level, though this is offset by excellent benefits.

job_title: Subsutiute in Oakland, CA
pros: Showing students that curriculums can be learning by understanding how to answer many ways.
cons: Development of new ways in teaching skills that produces understanding of skills to apply in every day skills in lesson learned .

job_title: Post Award Analyst III in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits are very generous and the work-life balance is great. State of the art gym if your're at the Mission Bay campus.
cons: Ultimately, it is a government job and the job can become very boring. It's up to yourself to be proactive.

job_title: Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Engaged teams across departments
- Talented co-workers
- Solution focused
cons:
- Department overhead
- Slow decision making
- Slow adoption of modern IT business tools.

job_title: Medical Social Worker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very inclusive of social work expertise on interdisciplinary team; great training; research focused; patient centered; culturally competent; strictly clinical social work, less case management as there are specific roles/positions to handle discharge plans.
cons: Parking is expensive; improve representation of women and POC in management positions

review_title: If you have talent to give, UCSF will make you shine but it's in your own hands to make it happen.
job_title: Programmer/Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: It's not corporate America, you get a relaxed work environment.  Plenty of different department to choose from.
cons: Budgets degrade technology advances in smaller departments.

review_title: World class institution, but faculty are expendable.
job_title: Assistant Adjunct Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is world class in basic sciences.
cons: UCSF has a culture, particularly in the med school, that faculty are expendable.  There is high turnover for a school of its stature.

job_title: Histotechnologist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good health and retirement benefits, stable employment, and top notch research and clinical MD's and health professionals.
cons: Very political. Upward mobility is difficult. The glass ceiling here is real.

review_title: Good experience but grant-funded positions can be tenuous
job_title: Analyst III in San Francisco, CA
pros: I had two different jobs as an analyst at UCSF and they differed widely. An employee's experience will vary depending on management style of the PI.
cons: In the positions I held, there was no room for career growth.

review_title: UCSF in Fresno was a horrible place to work. UCSF iin SF is a wonderful place to work
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Physicians are forward thinking and appreciate a desire to learn, therefore they are willing to teach.
cons: because its a acedemic setting the pay is not as great as the benefits.

job_title: Senior Statistician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great people.  Wonderfully committed and smart co-workers.  Great work/life balance
cons: Bureaucratic, Red Tape and slow to get things done.  Pay is very low.  Not competitive especially in the Bay Area where cost of living is high

job_title: Member Services Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits, and the consistency of raises. The benefits are unmatched anywhere else. Raises are in steps and are consistent every year.
cons: The management and ancient workplace practices

job_title: Senior Statistician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits; great work schedule; some great co-workers; opportunities to learn new professional skills
cons: Some dysfunction in departmental management; recession severely impacted jobs and department resources from 2009 - 2013

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Good work environment
good benefits
Generous paid vacation and sick days
extensive paid holidays
cons:
Low salaries for highly qualified professionals
Hard to grow within

job_title: Educational Research Analyst in San Rafael, CA
pros: Great network of people, amazing research opportunities, great managers and an overall good experience. Loved the guest speakers and events
cons: A very quiet environment and not much interaction with other colleagues. It's an older crowd making it difficult for young people

review_title: UCSF School of Medicine Senior Strategic Role
job_title: Director, Strategic Communications in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good work life balance, organizational integrity, forefront of scientific and clinical advancements
cons: Bureaucratic, can be cumbersome to execute projects, no bonuses, raises difficult to secure depending on department, very difficult to let go of underperforming employees

review_title: Great place for research training and gaining experience to advance your career
job_title: Associate Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent mentors, research collaborators, facilities on par with best Academic institution, Famous
cons: High cost of living in SF, poor salary, extra hours of work that you have to put in

job_title: Assistant Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: Flexibility, interesting research, driven coworkers, takes care of employees well. There is a lot of prestige when working here.
cons: My P.I. couldn't have honestly cared less about his employees unless they were post-docs, or had two letters following their name.

job_title: Service Desk Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits are great and free shuttle service in San Francisco.
cons: There seems to be some type of outage or application that is always going down at UCSF on a daily basis.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits and retirement plans are good and the opportunity to be involved in meaningful work.
cons: No training, gossipy environment, condescending employees with big egos.

job_title: Business Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: UC Benefits and retirement plan
cons: Unless you are desperate for a job, do not work here. I was hired as a marketing and business development analyst but was doing billing for over six months.

job_title: Analyst I in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Room for advancement
Some coworkers were great people
Decent benefits
Free Shuttle
cons:
Reviews were unfairly skewed to keep employee doubting abilities. 
Virtually no reliable documentation/procedures
Thus, training onus was on other experience employees, which caused tension between the trainer and new-hire.

review_title: Great benefits, experience depends on department
job_title: Communications Manager in Oakland, CA
pros:
Great benefits and pay for a public institution
Good people depending on the person and department
Great mission/goal
Good work
Niche institution
cons:
Suffers from overworking staff like public higher education institutions
Serious and competitive culture that creates silos and disjointed community
No central campus that feels academic

review_title: A great place for retirement -- or a career break
job_title: Programmer/Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work-life balance. Doing a "meaningful job", helping accomplish the mission of the University: education and research.
cons: As a member of the IT staff, my salary is 20% lower than in the industry.

job_title: Assistant Budget Analyst in Pleasanton, CA
pros: Convenient, opportunity to make a lot of connections, many jobs offered, claim that fluidity is easily achieved
cons: Not very professional, working in a medical setting, word gets around very easily and very quickly, a lot of office and budget politics, low salary

review_title: Fantastic place to conduct research in basic science
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: At the mission bay campus of ucsf I had a wonderful experience conducting research as a postdoc. The university offers a stimulating intellectual environment and many opportunities for collaboration.
cons: postdoctoral salaries do not afford a comfortable lifestyle

review_title: Some Departments are very terribel to work.
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great retirement and health benefits
cons: Just be careful which department you will accept the position.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits are hard to beat
cons: They talk a lot about "work-life balance" and "supportive work environment", but I've never experienced such toxicity on such a colossal scale.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has great retirement benefits. If you are looking somewhere to settle down, UCSF is good for that.
cons: Some researchers act high and mighty which creates a heirarchical culture. If you are at the bottom of the totem pole you'll feel it.

job_title: Analyst III in Richmond, CA
pros: Some of the most intelligent people in the world work for UCSF...such a groundbreaking university!
cons: Salaries are where they should be.  Salary increases should occur without there being an increase in pension contribution/benefits.  In reality it's not a pay increase.

job_title: Senior Surgical Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great  benefits, high acuity vases, lots of research. Talented medical staff.
cons: Catty nurses , useless hierarchy  and lack of growth for non nursing carreers

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great minds and an opportunity to bridge clinical medicine with basic medical research
cons: lack of integration. Lack of caring for medical science at the expense of paperwork.

review_title: Great exposure to the real world.
job_title: Staff Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of research positions open to new college grads with minimal experience.
cons: Career development without a secondary degree is difficult since most people who are hired will move on to graduate school or a biotech company.

job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits. Mission of UCSF and its role in global healthcare gives you a sense of pride and happiness.
cons: An unprofessional Director/Manager can make the departmental work environment toxic.

review_title: The practice managers have too much power, They BLOCK RN transfer for NO REASON
job_title: RN CNII in San Francisco, CA
pros: The Money was Great, the benefits Outstanding
cons: The practice mangers who WERE NOT NURSES, Ran the Show like they were given some special authority from GOD, They were NOT medical professionals but acted as if they were.

job_title: Analyst IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: Flexible, Pension program is great. People are good to work with.
cons: little room for advancement, lack of bonuses and reglar cost of living increases makes it difficult to live in Bay Area. Very bureaucratic and slow.

job_title: Junior Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: I worked here for 3 years. The intelligent and nice people make the working culture very comfortable and energetic.
cons: have little chance to get the better position.  a lot of talented person went to other places finally.

job_title: Executive Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great amount of time off, all school holidays. Good benefits.
cons: Just like any job some departments are better than others. If you are in a department where most people have been there for over 15 years run.

job_title: Associate Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great reputation and some really bright people
cons: UC system has fixed salaries that are not in line with Bay Area cost of living.  For this reason, the research faculty have trouble retaining senior talent.

job_title: Dietetic Intern in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great stipend, amazing interdisciplinary staff, one of a kind opportunity to learn from some of the best dietitians in the Bay Area in a tertiary hospital
cons: Can be very stressful and busy, sometimes competitive

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: Combination of clinical and basic scientific research, as well as access to industry
cons: Places like Berkeley have more excellent classes (even if they represent a small percentage of what is offered).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are a lot of good labs, no undergrads, and people are exceptionally relaxed for being such a top-rate institutions.
cons: It's a post doc. You have a PhD, and make $42,000 a year with zero job security.

review_title: Great place to work, great place for research!
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Collaborative, supportive environment. UCSF is a great facility doing cutting-edge research.
cons: Bureaucratic red-tape can sometimes slow down the science.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good benefits, generous vacation time/holidays, casual work environment, working with diverse groups, good work/life balance
cons: Salaries could be more competitive, difficult to advance/be re-classified

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great scientific and collegial atmosphere, very collaborative. UCSF is very committed to diversity and inclusion. Great benefits and vacation. Great overall place to work at!
cons: HR can be hard to get a hold of

review_title: Great institution, my unit has issues
job_title: Msp in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a wonderful institution--great school, great people, would preferentially seek treatment there.
cons: Insufficient support and service staff, extremely hierarchical management structure that make for inefficiencies and blame that trickles downwards.

job_title: Clinical Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great training, great exposure. You have access to great attendings and you have the opportunity to participate in clinical trials.
cons: Work life balance can be difficult as one would expect for a clinical fellow. Call schedule can be heavy.

review_title: It's great institute, met a lot of talented people.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of smart postdocs from all over the world. Learn a lot from them.
cons: Depend on the PI, my group was very research orientated, no time for career exploration.

review_title: The best school you've never heard of
job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Top 10 university in anything graduate level in healthcare and life sciences.
cons: Nobody's heard of it outside of the Bay Area or the industry

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of high quality employees work at UCSF Medical Center, all of whom are striving for the best patient care experiences.
cons: UCSF Med Center is a large operation, and it can take a while for things to change

review_title: Bureaucratic, but great place to learn
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Networking, fair, kind, can learn a lot, professional
cons: bureaucratic, boring, monotonous at times, don't get the small company feel that SF is all about

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Top University, highly collaborative environment, plenty of opportunities. Nice city and very nice people.
cons: Absurdly expensive, or even unaffordable, for postdocs with 40-50K annual salary.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great career opportunity where you can learn and grow.  The doctors were very down to earth and helpful
cons: Constant work since the studies consist of working with different universities in different time zones

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good environment for those looking for a position before graduate school. There’s a lot of opportunities to learn and like minded colleagues.
cons: Underpaid for the work needed. Wouldn’t want to be there long term.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Flexible work environment, high quality research. Researchers are intelligent and engaged in their work, you can learn a lot from them.
cons: Pay is low for San Francisco living, bureaucratic system can be a headache.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, excellent innovative culture, excellent and cool science!!
cons: Poor pay -- but that's not specific to UCSF -- all places pay postdocs peanuts for their qualifications

job_title: Specialist II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Health benefits are pretty good. Day-to-day schedule is flexible, so long as you work all 8 hours.
cons: Lack of resources due to limited funding. Isolated environment - limited mingling between staff in different departments.

job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Fantastic place to learn under supportive Directors
cons: Slow paced environment with low turn-over

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Never work past 5pm
benefits
nice people
cons:
lower pay than average
old school mentality. can't work from home.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Some of the best co-workers I've ever had, everyone is really nice, brilliant minds all around you
cons: Salaries are not as competitive as other medical jobs (i.e. biotech)

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Research advancement, learning environment, good entry level job to get hands on experience in the lab
cons: Overload of work, relatively low pay for the high cost of living area, no upward mobility for this position

review_title: A nice place to work for 3 year maximum
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: great environment, employees and facilities
cons: long hours, low pay, isolation

job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: excellent research, excellent scientific community
cons: very low pay, very little reward, long hours. the career center at ucsf, unfortunately, is not great.

review_title: So-called career path is difficult to understand or benefit from
job_title: Human Resources Generalist II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Employees get discounted gym membership at Parnassus and Mission Bay
cons: It's really hard to get a job here for some reason, and it's even harder for most to advance.

job_title: Staff Research Associate I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great atmosphere and a good working environment, good benefits and job security
cons: Difficult to move up, lots of red tape to get things done, administration at university often inefficient

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: The best research institute,  a lot of opportunities to learn new things but stressful
cons: need to be independent and learn by yourself.  People expect you to know and

job_title: Finance Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work for an organization that's trying to accomplish amazing things. Be proud of its mission and growth.
cons: Advancement and development can be limited.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Staff great to work with. Committed to doing great work
cons: The administration needs sugnificant improvement in overall management and leafership,.  Processes and procrdures require significant improvememts. Mandatory retirement contribution is 8% moving to 10%.

job_title: CSWIII Supervisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Challenging work with complex patients, great teamwork & atmosphere, opening to learning, flexible in responses, leadership values employees
cons: Ever changing protocols, increasing workload

review_title: Very low salaries for San Francisco
job_title: Lab Assistant II in San Francisco, CA

Benefits are good
Top Scientists
Flexible hours
cons:
Slow to promote
Grossly underpaid for living in San Francisco
Parking very hard or very expensive.

review_title: Full Specialist III at Applied Genomics Laboratory (UCSF)
job_title: Full Specialist III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great program, great PI (Dr. Il-Jin Kim). I'm having a great time and learning a lot.
cons: Not really much cons if you are a hard worker and love Genomics.

review_title: Not enough pay but good on your resume
job_title: Marketing Programs Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Steady paycheck. Great health benefits.
cons: Not enough pay for San Francisco. A LOT of bureaucracy and politics. Good for anyone looking for something stable and can tolerate redundancy and boredom.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Top researchers in respective fields work at UCSF
cons: University consists of little fifdoms and staff are not treated consistently across the University.

review_title: Great if your in the medical field, stay away if you are looking for an admin job!
job_title: Assistant III in Las Vegas, NV

cons: Very bureaucratic, hostile work environment

review_title: It all depends on who you know.
job_title: Research Analyst in Las Vegas, NV
pros: If you are able to build a decent network, you can go far within the university.
cons: Unqualified individuals in key positions, which would never fly in the corporate work sector.

job_title: Personal Trainer in San Francisco, CA
pros: The insurance is good, members are open to different types of training.
cons: Bad managerial decisions day in and day out, no career advancement, no trainer support/ continuing education and no social media help.

review_title: UCSF-- AN AWESOME PLACE TO WORK
job_title: Analyst III  in San Francisco, CA
pros: IT IS A BIG FAMILY. EVERYONE (FOR THE MOST PART) IS VERY FRIENDLY AND HELPFUL. THE CAMARADERIE IS WONDERFUL.
cons: THE BUERACRACY OF THE ADMINISTRATION

job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Top-notch scientific powerhouse.  Lots of resources for research.  Great location in the city.  New Mission Bay facilities.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy.  Cost of living is high in San Francisco.

review_title: Great place to grow as a scientist
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: great research great scientist perfect place to learn and do science.
cons: All your colleagues are as good as you and are probably looking for a job too.

job_title: Research Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Stable place to work with good benefits. Flexibility to work remotely and free shuttles for commuting.
cons: Pay is low, especially compared to the cost of living in SF. Not much opportunity for advancement.

review_title: Great place to finish your career.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA

cons: Salaries that don't compete with market. Slow paced environment. Leans heavily on the perks of it's pension as though it offsets  salary inequity.

job_title: Executive Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: You can move around internally especially if you network with the staff
cons: The pay. You get lowballed and then stuck with that amount. Even if they add work that wasn’t in your job description.

review_title: Great Quality Research, excellent place for a focused short time to take your next career step

review_title: UCSF is a fun and vibrant place for biological research.

Is a rewarding work environment for good science and collaborative work .

job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Junior Specialist in San Francisco, CA

Very robust environment
No leisure/recreational time

job_title: Financial Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: No unapproved overtime, work is stable, and benefits are nice.
cons: Depending on your department, there is no working from home.

job_title: Executive Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work that matters, people that care, recognized worldwide
cons: Large, public, decentralized institution means getting stuff done takes tenacity

review_title: Good work environment that encourages professional development
job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Flexible hours
Encourages professional development
Good culture

job_title: Junior Specialist in San Francisco, CA

cons: Money, not many opportunities to grow. Also what's typical for academia is work/life ratio.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Director in San Francisco, CA

cons: C-suite is dysfunctional, most departments function in a silo.

job_title: Associate Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Faculty, location, benefits, infrastructure, work culture.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Many excellent researchers. Easy to collaborate. good benefit. most people are nice.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA

cons: Very bureaucratic, hard to get anything done quickly and merit based increases or bonuses are nearly impossible

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA

review_title: UCSF is a good place to work

Choose your PI carefully.
None of them are bad, but it's personality dependent.
